item.title: Markus March 19th Punchlines
item.description: Victoria Status Brainstormed ideas for the Dashboard. Went through draft Dashboard contents with Karen and Farah and got some good and constructive feedback Next Steps With the feedback I got back regarding the potential Dashboard contents, come up with a preliminary prototype — one that we can take apart and help establish a better idea as to how we’d like to design the Dashboard. Roadblocks Swamped with work (from my full-time position).

item.description: The MarkUs team is plowing forward, fleshing out some fantastic new features, and kicking a bunch of bugs to the curb! You can read our meeting minutes here.

item.title: MarkUs February 26th Punchlines
item.description: The MarkUs teamâ€™s status punchlines for this week can be found here.

item.title: Brian Xu â€“ Midway Update
item.description: The time is running so fast that it is already the middle of the term.Â It has been a quite exciting time for me since I joined UCOSP, joined my team â€“ MarkUs. After 2 months work with our team, I feel more confident in working for MarkUs. What I have learned For the technique aspect, I am more familiar with Rails development. I have learned setting up the workspace for Rails, basic Ruby syntax and basic way of Rails development.

item.title: Joseph's Midterm Report
item.description: Summary: Things are going slower than expected. I thought I would be able to get so much more done. The first few weeks were spent on my first changelist. My expectation was to be done with the first week [8]. I have learned tons about Ruby, Rails, Rails plugins and javascript. I am currently working on replaced the AJAX pagination with serverside pagination on the submissions page. Afterwards, I will be working on the detailed view for the submissions page.

item.title: Victoria Mui â€“ Midway Update
item.description: Expectations, Status & Progress Coming into this UCOSP project course, my ultimate goal was to be able to utilize the human-computer interaction (HCI) and user experience (UX) design knowledge that Iâ€™ve acquired from both school and work to enhance the usability of MarkUs.Â Through this experience, Iâ€™m hoping to solidify my understanding of various usability concepts and familiarize myself with more projects out there. Up until now, I feel that Iâ€™m on track with the work that Iâ€™m doing with MarkUs.

item.title: Bryan Shen's Midterm Report
item.description: Two months have passed since I joined Markus in Undergraduate Capstone Open Source Project (UCOSP). I thought it was just another course, but it’s a completely different than every other one I’ve ever taken. The most noticeable difference is that no instructor is around! In a regular course, I am told how to do stuffs. I sit in a comfortable chair in the classroom, follow the instructions given by teachers and do best I to meet their expectation.

item.title: Farah's Midway Update
item.description: The first half of the semester has flown by quickly. Like last semester, I’m really enjoying being a part of the MarkUs team! It was nice to already have my development environment from last semester all set and ready to go for this semester. Since I didn’t have to spend any time on setup, I was able to jump back into the code right away. I’ve found that things make a lot more sense to me now than they did around the same time last semester.

item.title: Robert's Midway Update
item.description: Simply put, I’m dissatisfied with my performance with MarkUs. Up until now, I’ve been doing what could be considered the bare minimum of work to get a passing “grade” for UCOSP.Â This is my final school term which means I’m looking to the future a lot this term, searching for full time employment. While I’ve been very successful in this endeavour to tell the truth, it does mean that certain trade offs have been made which have not been to MarkUs’ benefit.

item.title: MarkUs Status Update – Feb. 5th, 2010
item.description: The MarkUs team’s status punchlines for this week can be found here.

item.title: The hidden power of ruby's "next" keyword
item.description: Just blogged about this on my blog today, which might be of interest to the MarkUs folks.

item.title: Markus Status Update!
item.description: … can be found here . If you make it to the bottom, you can see that I haven’t done very much. Interviews take up so much time! It’s a good problem to have, but I can’t help be feel a bit of guilt for pushing MarkUs off to the side for them. Because of the flexible nature of UCOSP, it’s possible for me to do this. I’m just using my banked up hours from the code-sprint sooner rather than later.

item.title: MarkUs Meeting Minutes
item.description: MarkUs had it’s first IRC meeting of the term. It’s a slow beginning but I think we’ll start moving quickly soon enough. : ) See the minutes here.

item.title: MarkUs Team Status Reports for Jan 22, 2010
item.description: It was a slam dunk code-sprint weekend for the MarkUs team.Â Lots of coding, learning, and getting to know one another. Click here to check out our punchline status reports for this week.

item.title: Joseph Mate
item.description: Hey everyone, Joseph Mate My name is Joseph. I am in 3B Computer Science at the University of Waterloo and will be working with MarkUs this term. I have not worked an open source project before; however, I am eager to start. I have lots of experience with Java from school and work. I have a little experience with C#, Python and Unix Shell Programming. I recently started playing around with Ruby and this term will be an excellent opportunity to extend what I already know.

item.title: Robert Burke
item.description: Hello! I’m in my final term of a Bachelor of Computer Science. I’ve learned from co-ops at Maplesoft, RIM, Amazon.com and Next Level Games, where I’ve been a scriptor, a build monkey, a manual tester, a Java jockey, and a C++ centurion. I have no favourite language, because I can pick them up easily enough. I enjoy solving problems and learning new things. I’ll be working on the MarkUs Project this term from winter-laden Waterloo.

item.title: Brian Xu
item.description: Hi all! I am Brian Xu from SFU and currently experiencing my last year of undergraduate. It feels really exciting when I received the admission mail to UCOSP. My latest projects experience are all related to web development such as leading a team to develop a website using Flex/PHP/MySQL, and working in HSBC for 8 months on website configuration andÂ development. I am sure MarkUs is another great opportunity to broaden my knowledge about web development and also to learn from you genius!

item.title: Bryan Shen
item.description: Hello everyone, I’m Bryan Shen, a 5th year CS student from SFU. I’m very glad to have the chance to work with you guys on Markus. I’ve been enjoying programming ever since the first time I said “hello world” in C. Now my major languages are C-style ones such as Java and C#, and I’m now working with ASP.net web development. I’m eager to learn new technologies, and I believe it’ll be a joy to shift to Ruby on Rails from my past experience.

item.title: Victoria Mui
item.description: My name is Victoria Mui, and I’m a 4th year student currently completing my undergraduate specialist degree in Computer Science (Software Engineering) at the University of Toronto.Â This coming spring/winter term, I’ll be working on the user interface design of the MarkUs online marking tool. I’m primarily a Java programmer, and I’ve made contributions to the Cytoscape open source community through the Google Summer of Code 2008 program under the mentorship of Professor Greg Wilson.

item.title: Markus: Flexible Marking Scheme ScreenCasts…
item.description: Eventhough it is published on our DrProject since December first, we forgot to let you know that our screencasts are done. Please follow this links: – Select a marking scheme – Add flexible criterion Enjoy watching theme ðŸ˜‰

item.description: You’ll find this week’s MarkUs status update here.

item.title: MarkUs Weekly Meeting
item.description: The MarkUs team had its weekly meeting today. Have a look at the meeting minutes.

item.title: Winter 2010 Project #9: MarkUs
item.description: MarkUs is an open-source tool which recreates the ease and flexibility of grading assignments with pen on paper, within a web application. It also allows students and instructors to form groups, and collaborate on assignments. MarkUs is implemented in Ruby on Rails, and every line of code has been written by undergraduate students. It is currently used in 3 classes at the University of Toronto. There are plans to use it for one course in Waterloo starting in January with the hopes of expanding our user base in the Fall of 2010.

item.title: My Tools of the Trade
item.description: Here’s a list of tools I cast essential for carrying out my day-to-day business or I find otherwise useful. Hardware (in no particular order)** ** My primary workstation is a HP Pavillion Slimline, a pretty much standard, off-the-shelf PC on which I installed Ubuntu Linux. The hardware works reasonable well under Linux, but at some point I wish hardware vendors would just offer some models which work seamlessly with any major OS.

item.title: Code Sprinting with MarkUs – Day 3
item.description: Like the first two days of the code sprint, yesterday was a very productive day for the MarkUs team. Review Board continued to receive a workout as review requests kept coming in. We also had a meeting in the afternoon to discuss our tasks for the rest of the semester. You’ll want to check out the exciting new features that we are planning on adding to MarkUs!

item.title: Codesprinting with MarkUs â€“ Day 2
item.description: The MarkUs team spent day 2 of the Codesprint plowing through a boatload of code; writing, patching, reviewing, committing…

item.title: Codesprinting with MarkUs – Day 1
item.description: The MarkUs team is planning on writing a more detailed post after the weekend is out, but until then, here’s a preview to wet your palette.

item.description:
The Basie team posted their first-day report on their blog. No word yet from Ingres or MarkUs, but we’re hopeful ðŸ™‚ And just to prove we’re all here: Basie Eclipse4Edu
ElmCity

item.title: Status Updates
item.description: Here are the latest progress reports from the teams (with Ingres, Thunderbird, and WikiDev still to come): Basie * Build a toy application in Django and check it into the Subversion repository to prove that they have started learning the framework. Get Basie running on their development machine and send us a URL so that we can check it. Fix some of our broken test fixtures (long story) and put their changes up for code review.

item.title: MarkUs IRC Meeting, Week 2
item.description: The MarkUs team had their second IRC meeting earlier today. Read our meeting notes Looking forward to meeting all of you next week at the code sprint! The MarkUs Team

item.title: MarkUs Status Update
item.description: The MarkUs team has spent the week getting their development environments set up.Â Thanks to a little elbow grease, we seem to be up and running on Linux, OSX, and Windows! One new team member has even gone so far as to get a patch reviewed, submit it to the repo, and close a ticket.Â And it was also MarkUs’s 1000th revision!Â What an awesome start!Â Great job, team! You can read more about our current status here.

item.title: The MarkUs Team Has Their First IRC Meeting
item.description: The MarkUs team had their first IRC meeting today. Check out the minutes on our blog, here. Or you can read the transcript here.Â (Meeting starts around 16:04) Cheers, -MarkUs Team

item.title: Simon Lavigne-Giroux
item.description: Hi, I am Simon Lavigne-Giroux. I’m at my fourth year in software engineering at UniversitÃ© Laval. I’m studying in this domain because I wanted to use my favourite tools, computers, completely. I alsoÂ really like the logic and problem resolution in software programming. In the past year, I’ve developed web applications in Java using Spring MVC and other frameworks. I’m excited to learn Ruby on Rails on the MarkUs project. It is also my first experience on an open source project.

item.title: Gabriel Roy-Lortie
item.description: Gabriel Roy-Lortie Gabriel Roy-Lortie is a fourth year student in software engineering at UniversitÃ© Laval who just joined the MarkUs team. Beside his full-time studies, he’s already had some part-time jobs in the CS field. He used to work for the FactultÃ© de Science et de gÃ©nie (Sc. and Eng. Faculty) on the design/maintenance/support of courses web sites and other IT-supported teaching material. Main technologies involved included PHP, MySQL, HTML, CSS, Javascript and the CMS Typo3.

item.title: Ainsley Lawson
item.description: ainsley_lawson Hey, I’m Ainsley, and I’ll be working on MarkUs this semester. I’m going into my final year at U of T Scarborough, where I am doing a double major in Computer Science and Psychology.Â The plan is to go to grad school (for CS) after I graduate. This summer, I worked for Professor Steve Easterbrook to develop a tool that helps software development teams understand improve their social networks (research blog here).

item.title: Fernando Garces
item.description: Hi, everyone. My name is Fernando Garces and I’ll be working MarkUs project Iâ€™m in my fourth and hopefully last year of my computer science degree with soft engineering option at the University of Waterloo. My primary areas of interests are databases, networks and OS, and the only think that I not very keen of are compilers. This is my first time working with Ruby on Rails so I hope it is not too painful to learn.

item.title: Enrolment Is Now Closed
item.description: With the acceptance of two students from the UniversitÃ© de Sherbrooke, enrolment is now closed for the Fall 2009 term. Our teams stand like this: Alberta Carleton Laval MSU MUN SFU Sherbrooke UBC UT UTM UTS UVI UVic Waterloo Total Basie 1 1 2 2 1 7 Eclipse4Edu 1 1 2 1 5 ElmCity 2 2 1 5 Ingres 2 2 3 7 MarkUs 3 2 1 2 8 RoboCup 2 3 1 6 Thunderbird 1 1 1 2 5 WikiDev 2 2 2 6 Total 3 1 3 5 1 6 2 1 11 2 1 5 2 6 49 Groups will be having their first team meetings online this week, and will start arriving in Toronto for the code sprint in two and a half weeks.

item.title: Farah Juma
item.description: Hi, I’m Farah Juma and I’m going to be working on MarkUs this fall. I’m a fourth year computer science student at the University of Toronto. I’m doing a specialist in artificial intelligence. I just completed a 16-month internship at Red Hat, as part of the Professional Experience Year program at U of T. I was on the JBoss Application Server team. It was an amazing experience and I learned a lot!

item.title: Severin Gehwolf
item.description: Hi! I am Severin Gehwolf, a second/third year Computer Science student at University of Toronto. Before coming to Toronto – starting my second degree – I was working for almost 2 years. It was then when I realized what interests me most: Software and its very internals. I got involved with MarkUs and Ruby on Rails during winter term 2009, but really didn’t do any Rails development until this summer when I started to work on MarkUs full-time.

item.title: Melanie Gaudet
item.description: Hi All! My name is Melanie Gaudet and I am going to work on MarkUs project this fall.Â I have started my journey with computers by a 3 years study in computer science(CEGEP). I have been hired in a great company, first as Progress databaseâ€™s administrator, and then as programmer-analyst and finally as project leader. The programming language I have been using the most so far is Progress, but I have tried many others so even though I have never worked with Rubby, I know that I will learn.

item.title: Tara Clark
item.description: Mount St. Helens, WA Hi, my name is Tara Clark and I’m going to be working on the MarkUs project this fall. I am a 4th year Computer Science and French student at the University of Waterloo. I love web programming and learning new languages (both natural and programming!) I first started out with web programming about 6 years ago and this will be my first time working with Ruby on Rails.

item.title: Mike Conley
item.description: Mike Conley Hi, I’m Mike Conley, and I’m one of the TA’s for this course.Â I will be helping Karen Reid manage the MarkUs Project this semester.Â I’m a Masters student at the University of Toronto in the Software Engineering group, and I just finished my undergrad at UofT, doubling in Computer Science and Dramatic Arts. I’ve been working on MarkUs since September, 2008.Â I’ve been web programming in one form or another for over a decade, but MarkUs has been my first time working on a fairly sophisticated Ruby on Rails project.

item.title: Testing Rails
item.description: Adam Goucher taught me most of what I know about quality assurance. He’s now in charge of the same at Zerofootprint, as well as a regular speaker at agile and testing conferences, and has kindly agreed to give the MarkUs team some guidance this fall.Â (Basie and Thunderbird teams take note: much of what he says applies to you too.)Â His thirty-second guide is a good place to start; I look forward to hearing more from him.

item.title: MarkUs and Basie This Fall
item.description: Over on the MarkUs blog, Karen Reid has posted an introduction to the team for the fall, and promised to outline projects the students might take on. Meanwhile, Bill Konrad has posted some project ideas for Basie, and I’ll follow up with an introduction to the team later this week. We should have all our students in place by the end of this week; things will start moving pretty quickly once Labor Day has come and gone.
